title: Comfort & Ease
description: Explore how comfortable and at ease you feel together physically

questions.text: I feel relaxed in my partner's physical presence.

therapeutic.rationale: Physical relaxation in your partner's presence indicates safety. Tension may signal unresolved issues, anxiety, or dynamics worth exploring.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner isn't relaxed, explore what creates tension. Is it about the relationship? Their own body? Past experiences?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared physical relaxation in each other's presence creates a calm foundation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you relax in your partner's physical presence?

questions.text: Being physically close doesn't bring up anxiety for me.

therapeutic.rationale: Physical closeness that triggers anxiety rather than comfort signals something worth understanding—whether about the relationship, past experiences, or personal patterns.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If closeness creates anxiety for one partner, approach with compassion. Anxiety often has roots that deserve gentle exploration.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared freedom from anxiety during closeness creates space for connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does physical closeness ever bring up anxiety? What might that be about?

questions.text: I can be myself physically around my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Being yourself physically—not performing or hiding—requires acceptance. When you can exist naturally in your body with your partner, intimacy deepens.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't be themselves physically, explore what they're hiding or performing. Building acceptance takes time and intention.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to be yourselves physically creates authentic intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What aspects of your physical self do you feel free to show? What do you hold back?

questions.text: My partner seems comfortable in their body around me.

therapeutic.rationale: Sensing your partner's comfort in their body affects your experience. Their ease invites your ease; their discomfort can create concern or confusion.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner senses the other's discomfort, naming it gently opens conversation. Body comfort is often a sensitive topic that benefits from compassion.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared perception of mutual body comfort creates relaxed physical connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How comfortable does your partner seem in their body around you?

questions.text: Physical moments with my partner feel natural, not effortful.

therapeutic.rationale: Naturalness in physical moments suggests compatibility and ease. When physical connection requires effort, exploring what's creating friction can help.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If physical moments feel effortful for one partner, explore what's creating the effort. Mismatched rhythms? Uncertainty about what to do?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared naturalness in physical moments indicates comfortable compatibility.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do physical moments feel most natural? When do they feel effortful?
